properties.name: Capitol tunnels
properties.description: Posted by Midnightsociety  capitol square, richmond, vaFrom VTunderground.com\'s Mike: "When I was growing up in Richmond, I always heard stories about tunnels running under Capitol Square. Supposedly they connected the state Capitol building with the Govenor\'s Mansion, and even ran all the way to MCV. MCV students would even hide cadavers down there, if the old legends are to be believed. Well, the tunnels are real, I\'ve explored them. I have a pile of photos, I just can\'t post them on my website (for obvious reasons). They do connect the Capitol and the Govenor\'s Mansion, as well as a lot of other buildings in that area. And they DO run to MCV. Actually, I\'ve seen the master tunnel map, and the tunnel network is VERY extensive. Security is tight, of course, including locked gates and security cameras. No cadavers though."

properties.name: Fotheringay
properties.description: Posted by MidnightsocietyN 37° 11.441 W 080° 14.197Legend has it that Colonel George Hancock had himself buried either sitting or standing upright so that he could keep watch over his slaves, posthumously. The mausoleum can be seen overlooking the house and fields.

properties.name: Home Brewing Company tunnels
properties.description: Posted by Midnightsociety  Few people know that Peter Stumpfs operated a brewery on Church Hill around the late 1800s, and that there are still brewery caves UNDER Chimborazo Park. Unfortunately, the entrance is well-buried. During WWII they were actually going to be used as a bomb shelter for residents of Church Hill, in case of Nazi bombers.

properties.name: Libby Hill Park
properties.description: Posted by Midnightsociety  28th and East Franklin Streets, Richmond, VAIn this statue there\'s a monument to Confederate soldiers and sailors, which features a lone man standing on top of a tower. Back in old-school Richmond, parents used to tell their kids that the man would climb down and hunt for kids that stayed up too late.

properties.name: The Lost City / Elko Tract
properties.description: Posted by Midnightsociety  6000 Technology Boulevard, Sandston, VAFrom Wikipedia: "Elko Tract is a 2,220 acre (9 km²) tract of land in Henrico County, Virginia. It is considered one of Virginia\'s most infamous ghost towns due to its history as a decoy airfield during World War II and suspicious activity in the area afterwards."
